title: Genealogies of Tribes
shortSummary: 1 Chronicles 7 details the genealogies and military strength of several tribes of Israel, including Issachar, Benjamin, Naphtali, Manasseh, Ephraim, and Asher. This chapter highlights the importance of family lineage, tribal identity, and the readiness of God's people for battle during King David's reign. It serves as a record of God's faithfulness in preserving the tribes and their leaders.
timeline: c. 1010-970 BC - Reign of King David

keyCharacters.name: Issachar
keyCharacters.description: One of the twelve sons of Jacob; his descendants are listed with emphasis on their military might and leadership.

keyCharacters.name: Benjamin
keyCharacters.description: The youngest son of Jacob; his descendants are noted for their valor and genealogical records.

keyCharacters.name: Manasseh
keyCharacters.description: Son of Joseph; his lineage includes notable descendants and territorial possessions.

keyCharacters.name: Ephraim
keyCharacters.description: Another son of Joseph; his family history includes both triumphs and tragedies, illustrating God's providence.

keyCharacters.name: Asher
keyCharacters.description: One of Jacob's sons; his descendants are described as mighty men and leaders within their tribe.

definitions.definition: A record or account of the ancestry and descendants of a person, family, or tribe, used to establish identity and inheritance.
Warriors noted for their courage, strength, and leadership in battle.
Leaders or chiefs of family clans responsible for governance and representation within the tribe.
A woman who lives with a man but has lower status than his wife, often bearing children and forming part of the family lineage.

outline.heading: Descendants and Military Strength of Issachar
outline.description: This section lists the sons of Issachar and their descendants, emphasizing their leadership and large number of valiant men prepared for war, highlighting God's provision for the tribe's strength.

outline.heading: Genealogy and Valor of Benjamin's Sons
outline.description: The sons of Benjamin are named along with their families, noted for their might and readiness for battle, underscoring the tribe's important role in Israel's military.

outline.heading: Lineage and Families of Naphtali and Manasseh
outline.description: This passage records the descendants of Naphtali and Manasseh, including notable family connections and the mention of Zelophehad's daughters, illustrating God's care for inheritance rights.

outline.heading: Ephraim's Descendants and Territorial Holdings
outline.description: The genealogy of Ephraim is detailed, including the story of loss and mourning, the birth of Beriah, and the cities and lands possessed by Joseph's descendants, showing God's faithfulness in provision.

outline.heading: Asher's Families and Military Readiness
outline.description: The sons of Asher and their families are listed, described as choice and mighty men of valor, with a significant number prepared for war, highlighting the tribe's strength and leadership.

application: Recognize the importance of honoring and understanding your spiritual heritage and the legacy of faith passed down through generations.
Commit to being spiritually prepared and steadfast, like the mighty men of valor, ready to stand firm in the battles of life through prayer and obedience.
Value godly leadership and accountability within the family and church, following the example of the heads of fathers' houses.
Trust in God's providence and faithfulness to provide for His people, even in times of loss and difficulty, as seen in Ephraim's story.

keyVerses.text: And the sons of Tola; Uzzi, and Rephaiah, and Jeriel, and Jahmai, and Jibsam, and Shemuel, heads of their father's house, to wit, of Tola: they were valiant men of might in their generations; whose number was in the days of David two and twenty thousand and six hundred.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the strength and leadership within Issachar's tribe, showing God's blessing on their generations.

keyVerses.text: All these the sons of Jediael, by the heads of their fathers, mighty men of valour, were seventeen thousand and two hundred soldiers, fit to go out for war and battle.
keyVerses.significance: It emphasizes the readiness and valor of Benjamin's descendants, reflecting the importance of being prepared for spiritual and physical battles.

keyVerses.text: And Machir took to wife the sister of Huppim and Shuppim, whose sister's name was Maachah;) and the name of the second was Zelophehad: and Zelophehad had daughters.
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces Zelophehad's daughters, significant for their role in inheritance rights, illustrating God's justice and provision for women in Israel.

keyVerses.text: All these were the children of Asher, heads of their father's house, choice and mighty men of valour, chief of the princes. And the number throughout the genealogy of them that were apt to the war and to battle was twenty and six thousand men.
keyVerses.significance: It summarizes Asher's tribe as strong and well-organized, demonstrating God's blessing on faithful leadership and preparedness.
